dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The concert is over. The audience breaks up. Ethan and Grace, arm around each other (like lovers), move through groups of parents. Ethan carries his son’s Cello. Josh plays with his sister Emma and some other kids by a tree, they are catching fireflies.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Learner, Mr. Learner! Ethan turns. An ELEGANT LADY (40s) catches up, thrusts her hand out to Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Evelyn Williams. My son Jed is in your media studies class. He just loves that course. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Jed’s a clever guy, and fun to be around. You should be proud. This is my wife Grace. Josh and Emma run towards their parents. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT
dialogues.text: Hello. Do you teach also?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No, I’m a landscape designer. A tug on Grace’s skirt.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Mommy, mommy, look what Josh has got for me.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: We must get going. Tell Jed I said hello. Emma holds a glass peanut jar filled with fireflies.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Fireflies. They’re magic!

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Thanks again, good night. Grace walks away with Ethan who has his arm around her waist. Josh arrives, his hands cupped.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’ve got another one.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You were excellent, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You played beautifully. Josh is busy putting the firefly in the jar.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad. They arrive at their car, get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark now. A VOLVO STATION WAGON travels along a country road. GRACE (V.O. A big bath as soon as you get back young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan drives, Grace beside him. Josh and Emma in the back. (Prairie Home Companion is on the radio).

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The orchestra conductor says you're going inot the Northeast finals this semester. That’s exciting.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, we have practice Tuesdays and Saturdays.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Saturdays? What about our canoe trips?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t know, dad. It’s the finals. Garrison Kellior on the radio: “It got cold in Lake Wobegon, like your father just walked into the room.”

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I guess some people’s fathers are...how would you say it?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: They're severe, cross. They make people tremble.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Like when Mrs. Prendegast walks in the room at school. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: No. Mrs. Prendegast isn’t that bad.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Mom! Josh and Emma begin to study the fireflies. Ethan switches on the wipers, pushes the wiper button to clean the dirty screen. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (mutters) Damn.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Mommy Can I keep them in my room forever?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so sweetie, they might die. Emma starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I don’t want them to die. Will they die in the jar?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: It’s okay, we’ll let them go when we get home, won’t we Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sure, mom. The Volvo signals left and turns on to Reservation Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road, narrow and unlit, flanked by woods. Ahead lies A COUNTRY GAS STATION. INT. ETHAN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 6

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: I need to pee. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Can't it wait darling?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No mommy.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It’s alright. I need to get wiper fluid anyway. The Volvo pulls in and stops. Ethan, Grace and Emma get out. Josh picks up the glass jar, studies it. CLOSE ON the glass jar. There are two dead fireflies at the bottom of the jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan walks into the workshop. The AUTO REPAIRMAN, JIMMY MCBRIDE, looks up from an engine repair job. An old 13 inch TV, with rabbit ears, plays in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Working late tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Every night. Ethan already has a gallon of fluid in hand.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Give me three dollars. IN THE BACKGROUND, a sports news report on TV.

dialogues.speaker: SPORTSCASTER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: A marathon session at Fenway ended tonight with the Sox winning 6-4 in the twelfth. Ethan hands over three dollars.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Twelve innings. You’re not the only one working late.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Different pay scale. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: For sure. Is this stuff bio- degradeable?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Whatever it says on the label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FORD EXPLORER comes barrelling around a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan steps out into the night, reading the label, then looks up as a CAR comes from his left, the road is illuminated and in the blaze of light (from brights). He sees Josh standing between two clumps of bushes on an aisle by the road. Then there is a SCREECH of tires, and, suddenly, from his right, the dark SUV careens into the light of the car then they pass. Ethan is frozen, about to turn as the SUV veers toward his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace is holding the door open for Emma when she hears the awful tone of Ethan’s warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, frozen, makes out the shape of a man driving the SUV as it swerves in toward the aisle and his son steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DWIGHT ARNO (40ish) sees the terrified face of a young boy frozen in his headlights. He tries to brake. His cell phone flies against the windscreen.  13 14 15 16 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peanut jar falls, crashing through the grill and smashes the passenger side headlight of the SUV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan watches in terror as the SUV HITS JOSH, BOUNCES him sideways, and he disappears behind the clump of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh's body flies off to the side. At the same time: Inside, LUCAS ARNO (11), is asleep in the passenger seat. He flies forward, his face smashes into the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan is RUNNING NOW across the forecourt out onto the road. Behind him, A CRY:

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ethan! As he runs, he catches a glimpse of the red brake lights on the SUV further along the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, Dwight reaches across to Lucas, who is doubled up in pain, clutching his eye.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Then, Dwight looks in the mirror, sees a man (Ethan) standing in the road, staring, but Lucas is crying now.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Dad, dad, my eye! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus! Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: It hurts. Dwight cradles Lucas in his arms, on his face a look of absolute terror. Then a BUZZING SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan calls out to the SUV.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where’s Josh?! Josh! Ethan turns back toward the verge.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Josh! Then, the sound of an ENGINE REVVING. The SUV takes off. Ethan reaches Josh but, confused, he turns toward the fleeing SUV. He shouts, begins to run after it ...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight looks in the mirror again, then puts his foot on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s alright, I’m gonna take care of it. Don’t cry, please. The Ford Explorer speeds off into the night. Dwight reaches over to Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, stop crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Ethan sees Josh, lifeless, blood trickling from his ears. He falls to his knees beside his child. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, God, oh God, you’re alright, you're alright ... AAAHHH! A CRY OF PAIN, as he kneels on shattered glass.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (beyond terrified)

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He looks back, sees Grace running toward him, then, confused, she turns back toward Emma, who is frozen mid- forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Come on, stop crying, let me see. Lucas turns to him, the eye has begun to swell up.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: What happened Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: We hit a log. It was lying on the road. I’m sorry. It’s gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A King Kullen supermarket on the edge of town. Dwight’s Ford Explorer pulls into the almost deserted car park.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I‘1l only be a second. Dwight sprints across the car park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside, we see Dwight’s anxious trot along the aisles, past the registers, as he disappears, and reappears with a bag in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight jumps into the car. He has a pack of frozen peas. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Let me see that. Lucas turns his head, a full blown shiner is developing.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, put this on it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Peas! Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: They're frozen ... like an ice pack. Pitchers use it on their arms. As Lucas places the frozen pea pack on his eye, Dwight starts the Explorer. A STATE TROOPER CAR, SIRENS BLARING, LIGHTS FLASHING, races past on the road.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: What happened Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: We hit a log, a tree branch on the road. You didn’t see it?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: No dad. I didn’t see anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds first: CRICKETS, RADIO SQUAWK and STATIC. Then the state trooper car pulls in to join several others blocking roads at the accident site.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Negative. An AMBULANCE’S warping red light competes with the flashing lights of PATROL CARS in front of the gas station. SEVERAL POLICE are at work, stringing tape, directing cars away, taking measurements. Grace, visible in the backseat of the car, face tear- stained, lifeless. Emma curled on her lap, like a baby. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ethan stands in the middle of the road, stares over at the covered body of his son. He looks dead, crushed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir? SERGEANT KEN BURKE (40-ish), clean-cut, pulls a notebook and pen from his back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I need to ask you some questions about what occurred here. Ethan just stares at him. Underwater. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) Can you tell us exactly what you saw? Mr. Learner ... I have to do this, we have a crime, a fugitive and time is of the essence.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: It’s a terrible thing, Mr. Learner, but I need your best recollection.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) I was getting washer fluid.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: What time would this have been?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Time? I don’t ... it must have been close to nine. The game report was on ... on the TV. I came out ...

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE POLICE CAR 26
dialogues.text: Grace has Emma’s head buried in her chest.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Where’s Josh, Mommy? Grace's POV of the medics hovering over her dead son. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: They're taking care of him.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Is he going to be alright? Grace watches as the paramedics lift the body bag, she’s dying inside, but tries not to lie.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I... ahh ... your daddy’s with him. She holds Emma’s head against her so she can’t look.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: And the vehicle that hit your son came from the right? Ethan manages a nod. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) Could you describe it for me?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: A truck, an SUV...

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: You get the make?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No. Big ... medium ... dark, blue maybe.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Could you describe the driver? Ethan is frozen by his own uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He was ... ah ... no. Burke waits for more.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Christ ... I don’t know. It’s a blur. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: What was your son doing on the road? Ethan looks at him with tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (beyond pathetic) I don’t know. A long silence. Burke slips the notebook into his back pocket and clips the pen to his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: I understand. We’1ll continue tomorrow. One of my guys will drive you home. But Ethan’s no longer listening. Lost in the nightmare of his own helplessness, staring at the body bag.

dialogues.speaker: ETH
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving my son.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Mr. Learner but need to keep the body here for now. It’s a crime scene. I’m going to make sure everything is handled with the greatest respect. You’ve got family to look after. Please go home. The word ‘body’ cuts Ethan like a sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan gets in the back seat. A STATE TROOPER in the driver seat. Emma has cried herself asleep.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Home? The word is poison to her.  29 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Colonial house with a porch. A couple of lights on inside. RUTH WHELDON (mid-30s) is at the window, staring out. The Explorer turns into the driveway and stops with the single headlight beam shining over the porch. The door opens, Ruth emerges, flashlight in hand. She shines the flashlight toward Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What happened to you? She shines the light directly into Dwight’s face. (How could she know already?)

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Why, what’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You’re more than two hours late. Now the light is on Lucas and she sees him hold something to his eye as Dwight gets out of the SUV. RUTH (CONT’D) What the hell happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Take it easy Ruth. Now Lucas gets out, reveals his eye.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Did you do this?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What! Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Mom, wait.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Look at him! Lucas is between them now. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Please mom, it was an accident. We hit a log.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: There was a downed tree branch or something on a bend. We went over it and his head hit the ...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Why wasn’t he wearing a seat belt?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: He was ... he messed with it. I didn’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (as she examines Lucas) Oh God, look at this, you know what people are going to think?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: No Ruth, what are they going to think?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That you hit him again.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: When are you going to get off that lie. I did not hit him, I tried to hit you and I missed. NORRIS WHELDON (40-ish), insurance salesman, Ruth’s husband, rushes out of the house, intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, hey! Please, everyone take it easy. Let me see that Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Where the hell were you?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: We were at the ball game for Christ sake. Where the hell did you think we were?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Who knows with you. You’re two hours late. I called ten times. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dwight looks to Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One month, just one month you’ve been allowed to have him over the weekend and he comes back looking like this. Every time I cut you some slack, you mess it up.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You cut me slack?!

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You wanna go back before the court? I’11 have your visitation rights pulled in a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Please, everyone, lets take one step back from this. Dwight everything’s fine, get in the car. Ruth examines Lucas eye.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (to Norris) Do you think he needs to go to the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Don’t be so ...

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Dwight please! Ruth take Lucas inside. As Ruth leads Lucas away.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (to Lucas) Hey, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dad, I’1l1 call you tomorrow. Dwight smiles, nods “yes.”

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Dad, (holds up the peas) pee ... nuts. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ruth throws a disgusted look back at Dwight. Norris meanwhile has shone his light on the broken headlight.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: You better get that light fixed, Dwight. You’ll get ticketed.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks Norris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog - SALLIE, hears something, pricks up its ears, bounds to the living room window, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome old New England house, set amid a pleasant garden. A COP CAR pulls away as Ethan carries Emma towards the door. Grace follows closely into the house. EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. GARAGE - NIGHT 31 A two-bedroom ranch-style, with a single car garage. A place devoid of personality, a divorcee’s rental. Dwight pulls into the driveway. He lifts the remote for the garage door, starts it, then changes his mind. He gets out, walks around to the front passenger side, studies the grill guard and the broken headlight. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - NIGHT 32 Dwight paces into the living room, turns on TV, clicks through the STATIONS, and finds the local news, a report on deadlock in the Connecticut State Legislature. He wanders over to the door, he’s left the main door open, gazes through the screen door at the SUV. He goes to the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Connecticut, Stratton. Stratton police station. Dwight listens, mutters a number, hangs up. Then fumbles for a pen, scribbles, studies the number. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He opens the freezer, pulls out a bottle of Stoli vodka, pours some into a glass, takes a big swig, then spits it out.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit, fuck, shit! He collapses onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan is in their bed with Emma, who has her arms clamped around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: He’s not coming home? Why? She looks to the door in panic.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s mommy? Mommy! (TRACK out the door, along the hall, to the bathroom)

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE BATHROOM 33A
dialogues.text: Grace sits on the edge of the bath, listening to the ring of a cellphone, then a woman’s voice, a faint hello.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Mom. Mom, I’ve got some terrible news ... Grace tries to say the words, they can’t come out, instead silence, then gasps, then tears ... collapses, can’t speak. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAWN 34 Dwight is still on the couch, most of the bottle of vodka gone, and the ashtray full. He surf’s the RADIO STATIONS, stops at the local station. A News Reporter talking again about the deadlock at the State Legislature. Dwight gets up, wanders to screen door, sees the first rays of a glorious sunrise. Dwight’s POV of the Ford Explorer. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Connecticut state troopers are investigating a fatal hit and run accident on Reservation Road near Old Greenwich. The victim is believed to be a ten year old boy. No name has been released but State Troopers are appealing to anyone driving in the vicinity around 9 PM last night to contact them at 1-800-555-1212. On I-95 a tractor trailer accident closed down the southbound highway for over two hours last night ... CLOSE ON his face, forehead flat against the door window, as though his whole body needs support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A set of blinds open on a window revealing a glorious sunrise on a very pleasant back garden. The light streams in on Ethan, still in his t-shirt and boxers red eyed, from lack of sleep. He stares into the mirror, sees a spiderman towel hanging over the shower bar (or door). He takes it down, folds it carefully. EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAY (FORMERLY SCENE 39) 35A Dwight emerges, gets into the Explorer, and drives it into the garage. He gets out and pushes a button on the wall and ducks under the door as it starts to close. The evidence sealed up, he starts back to his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan, lies on the bed beside Grace. Emma asleep on the other side. He holds her.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I've got to go pick up the car. Your mother should be here soon. He goes to her, leans, kisses. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Don’t be long, please. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That can’t be mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan opens the front door. BLANCA, a Hispanic woman, with cleaning equipment in her hand, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Learner.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (shocked) Oh Blanca, it’s your day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace settles and looks at Emma sleeping then, a PIERCING CRY from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: BLANCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ahh, no! No not my Josh! Blanca’s voice cuts the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace rushes down the stairs in her nightdress and sees Ethan trying to console BLANCA.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh, Blanca, Blanca. Blanca has known Josh since he was a little boy. Her grief is raw. Emma stands at the top of the stairs looking frightened. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. BEDROOM - DAY (FORMERLY SCENE 36) 38 Dwight asleep, still clothed, in the fetal position, on the bed. He awakens, looks at the clock, it’s 10:05. He jumps up, rushes out.  39 40 41 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a thickset HISPANIC DRIVER who laughs at a joke by the morning DRIVETIME DJ. Ethan, in the back, scribbles in a note pad, raises his head, stares out the window at the work day morning hustle on this busy street: SCHOOL KIDS ON BIKES, COMMUTERS scurrying to the local train station, A COUPLE OF 14 YEAR OLDS, boy and girl, holding hands as they walk to school. Ethan’s cell rings, he studies the number, it reads DEAN PHILIP CLARKSON, he answers. The driver lowers the radio.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Hey Phil ... yeah. Sorry I can’t, Phil ... ah ... I’m not going to make it in today ... No, no... a family thing ... in fact, I’m not going to be in for a while. Ethan listens, as he’s asked what’s wrong, finally he drops his head, confesses.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look Phil, we've had a tragedy ... Josh was killed last night.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: (muffled) Jesus Christ, Ethan! How?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Hit and run. (a beat) Thanks, thank you. Let me call you later. CLOSE ON The rearview mirror and the driver's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Victorian house just outside the center of town. Clipped hedges out front and a small parking lot behind. A painted sign reads “Cutter and Associates.” (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A (similar) cab pulls up. Dwight gets out in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight hurries past the middle-aged, frumpy RECEPTIONIST, who is on the phone. He heads down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Dwight. INT. CUTTER & ASSOCIATES. STEVE CUTTER’S OFFICE - DAY 42A A smartly dressed, handsome man (50ish). This is Steve CUTTER, the owner and principle lawyer of the firm.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You in court this morning?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Nah, car trouble, the fucking transmission went on the Explorer yesterday, spent the morning dealing with it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How'd it go with Lucas this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Really good, why?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I got a call from Ruth this morning, said you were belligerent, brought Lucas home with a black eye.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Bitch. He smacked his eye on the dash. She threw a shit fit.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look buddy, you can’t get into situations with her. She drags us in front of that judge again you'll loose the sleep over. Nora Fennelli’s waiting. Dwight nods, mutters fuck to himself as he leaves.  23. 43 INT. CUTTER & ASSOCIATES. DWIGHT’S OFFICE - DAY 43 Dwight hurries in. NORA FENNELLI is reading an old New Yorker magazine.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Hey Nora, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Bored. I’ve been sitting here for forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Sorry, car trouble. You look good. Have you lost weight?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Only in my purse, thanks to the bills I get from you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight. The state trooper offices, clean, modern. The cab pulls up at the entrance. Ethan hands the driver some money.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Keep the change. As Ethan walks up the steps, he sees a battered old SUV, (dark blue) on a truck flat bed. He hurries.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did you get him? 45 INT. STATE POLICE BARRACKS. BURKE’S OFFICE - DAY 45 Ethan sits across from Sgt. Burke.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: No, I’m afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I saw an SUV out there.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Similar? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Well yeah, dark, the same shape. ETHAN’S POV - THROUGH A WINDOW - of the SUV. SERGEANT BURKE. We’ve had that since Saturday. You think that might be the model?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Well something like that. They sit again.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Good, we're getting somewhere. Let’s look at some similar makes.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What are the chances of this man turning himself in?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: In the first few days, very good. He’s drunk or high, he goes home, sobers up, realizes what he’s done and turns himself in. The longer it goes then surrender becomes less likely.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. STATE POLICE BARRACKS. BURKE’S OFFICE - LATER 46 CLOSE ON a Starbucks coffee cup placed on a desk.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Decaf latte. Ethan nods as the State Trooper sets it down. Ethan’s been there awhile now - files, photos are spread across Burke’s desk. Ethan sips, thinking, then ...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He shouted something.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: The driver. Yeah, that’s right a shout, sounded like Lo ... Look. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Look out maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I didn’t hear anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: No one else in the truck?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t see anyone. It all happened in a flash.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Did you notice anything unusual about the vehicle, snow plough attachment, grill guard. Ethan shakes his head “no,” uncomfortable with his lack of memory.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The reason I ask is that we usually find some debris from the impact: paint flakes, fiber glass, dirt the wheel well. There was none of that at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It was all so fast. Burke lifts some evidence bags from a box.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: We gathered up some items from around the scene, perhaps you could take a look. The first bag contains some crushed soda cans, empty cigarette pakcs. Ethan studies, shakes his head no. The Burke reaches in takes out another bag, its the peanut jar, intact, the lid is separate, the fireflies are gone. Etha’s look registers with Burke. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) You recognize that.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No.It is a peanut jar. Josh collected fireflies in it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: You think that’s why he got out of your car? To collect fireflies.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No. to let them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke walks Ethan to his car.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: This is a small town, Mr. Learner. We’ve mobilized all our resources. I'm hopeful we'll find this vehicle and catch this man quickly. Ethan acknowledges the support. Sergeant Burke hands Ethan a brown envelope. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) Victims Services have put together a package of brochures, advise about practical and legal aspect of dealing with this sort of crime. All our numbers are in there. Call any time.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Ethan gets in the Volvo, still dazed from the peanut jar revelation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, Dwight heads toward the exit door, stops momentarily at Cutter’s door. Steve is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (on phone) One second ... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I gotta get a rental ‘till I figure this car thing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps outside, a TAXI is waiting. He tries to breathe fresh air into his lungs. As he stands, Ethan’s car drives by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight. Grace is at the kitchen table, doing nothing. Shuffling papers, staring at Emma who sits on the outside porch drawing for her GRANDMOTHER BETH. Grace sees Ethan come up the porch stairs, take Beth is his arms, they embrace, profoundly. Ethan enters,

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It’s good your mother’s here. Grace gets up, moves toward him.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What did they say? Did they get anyone? He takes her in his arms. The embrace holds.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No. They don’t have anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Not anything?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Did you remember anything? Anything more? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I ahh, yeah I went over what I saw, tried to pick the make of his truck. Details. The embrace breaks, she looks in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What was he doing out of the car, Ethan? He’s silent, but Grace knows Ethan, reads his face.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Tell me Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: They found the peanut jar ...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The firefly jar? Where?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Broken, on the road.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, It was my fault. He was letting them go because I told him they might die! Ethan grabs her hands, holds on.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It was nobody’s fault.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But he went to the bushes, all over the stupid fireflies. Emma appears behind them holding a drawing.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: What happened to the fireflies? Did they die with Josh? Her grandmother scoops her up.  53 54

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 53
dialogues.text: EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAY 54 Dwight pulls up into the driveway in a rented, light colored, mid-size car, and parks it under the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan’s car pulls up. As he walks away from it we see he is at Reservation Road Now in the afternoon sunlight, autumn trees, under a clear sky. He walks the road, sees a softball square, an old cemetery. He wanders to the gas station. He stands by the gas pumps, staring up the road. Trying to force himself to see clues he missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the setting idyllic, trimmed bushes, carefully groomed lawn, fake roman pillars around the entrance to add style to the building. Ethan pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior tastefully depressing, wood panelling, abundant flowers soothing music. Ethan sits opposite the FUNERAL DIRECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: FUNERAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Were you thinking of cremation or burial? Ethan is stunned by the choice.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Cremation, no? I don’t know ...

dialogues.speaker: FUNERAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Some people prefer to have a place in a garden of remembrance to visit, care for. Others prefer cremation so that they can perhaps release the ashes in a favorite place ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late night. Grace and Ethan are at the kitchen table alone.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: .».. we can bury him in the cemetery, among the lines of headstones. Or we can take him to the place he loved most in the world, and let him become part of that. He takes her hand pulls her closer.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s take him to the shore. He kisses her, wipes tears from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Will I see him, one last time, the way he was?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m going mad Ethan. Why did this happen to us? What did we do to deserve this?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Don’t, we’ll get through it. They kiss, and cling to each other. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - DAY 59 CLOSE ON the local newspaper headline. “LOCAL BOY KILLED IN HIT AND RUN - POLICE APPEAL FOR HELP.” Pull back from photo and reveal: Dwight studying the photo, reading the article, the newspaper spread out on his breakfast bar. He drops his head and bangs it on the newspaper, again and again, harder and harder.  61 62 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same newspaper is on the counter top. Ethan has his arm around Grace as they read it together. They are in their funeral clothes

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Who gave them that photo?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It’s a school photo. It doesn’t matter. CLOSE ON the school photo of Josh smiling. Grace’s mother arrives in the kitchen with Emma, both dressed for the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMOTHER
dialogues.text: Here we are. Ethan picks Emma up in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: We'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s rental car pulls up and parks. He switches off the engine and stares out at: A church, some 100 yards away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the puzzled faces of SCHOOLBOYS and GIRLS - Josh's classmates - not used to dealing with death. This small Episcopalian church is crowded with Ethan’s FELLOW PROFESSORS, FAMILY AND FRIENDS, and a contingent of SCHOOL CHILDREN, who have gathered for this ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Ruth Wheldon, from High River school and some of her choir will sing Amazing Grace. Feel free to sing along in celebration of Josh. A SMALL CHOIR including LUCAS plays. Ruth Wheldon is on the piano, they launch into Amazing Grace, many in the church join in.  63 64 65 66 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight sits in his rental car, looks toward the church further down the street as the CROWD emerges from the service. Dwight takes off his sunglasses, stares. He watches as Ethan and Grace emerge with Emma, hand in hand between them. Dwight’s heart is pounding, his hand trembles, as though Ethan will look up and recognize him. He puts the sunglasses back on. Then his eyes widen in shock, because: He sees his ex-wife Ruth emerge from the church and console Ethan and Grace. Dwight starts the car, does a u-turn in the street, and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin has been placed in the HEARSE. Ethan, and Grace watch. GRACE’S MOTHER holds on to Emma. As the hearse pulls away, Grace can no longer hold her composure, she moves away from Ethan toward the hearse.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: (crying) No, no, please. Josh don’t leave us. Ethan is beside her now holding her as her mother comforts Emma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s Monday morning, a week has gone by. The house, an emblem of New England serenity. Ethan emerges, hand in hand with Emma. Grace in her bathrobe, hair unbrushed - watches from the window. Emma waves goodbye. The car takes off, now Grace is totally alone.  67 68 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Grace’s hand as she plugs the power cord of the answering machine back in. Presses play. The recorded message light shows 34. Her finger hovers over the ‘delete all’ button, about to hit it, then she stops, hits ‘play’. She listens to the first word of a message, a distraught voice, “Ethan, Grace...” she hits delete, next is “My God...” Delete. With each message, all Grace needs is the first syllable, then delete, faster, faster, the number dwindles, 22, 17, 11, 9, then the frantic tones of voice disappear. Now we hear “Hello Grace, its Walden, I have those white pines you ordered.” Delete. Grace, Judie Greenberg darling, my rockery’s ... Then:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey mom, I need rosin for my cello, it’s on top of my desk. Can you bring them with you? Love you. Bye.” She plays it again, again, transported back before the horror, then a BUZZ, another BUZZ. It’s the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace opens the door and reveals, A Mexican gardener, RAUL, and behind him out on the road, his TRUCK and his TWO MAN CREW, watching.

dialogues.speaker: RAUL
dialogues.text: Signora Grace, you were to meet us at the Greer house.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: RAUL
dialogues.text: The Greer house, the new job?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Have you got any other work you can do for a few days Raul?, I’m not feeling too good.

dialogues.speaker: RAUL
dialogues.text: (disappointed) I don’t have no big jobs... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Just a few days. A STATE TROOPER PATROL CAR pulls into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: RAUL
dialogues.text: Okay, Okay! Call you Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yes, call. Sgt. Burke emerges from his car, carrying a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there news? Burke takes in the sight of this beautiful disheveled woman in her bathrobe, finger-combing her hair. Burke comes forward. Grace eyes the bag. SERGEANT BURKE (CONT’D) I told your husband I'd drop by?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: He’s taking our daughter to school. What is ...

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Forensics have returned your son's belongings. She stands back from the door, and Burke enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace and Sgt. Burke sit in oppressive silence.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ethan should be back soon.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: (helpfully) Yeah he said he’d be here. Grace looks down at the bag. Goes to reach out. Burke throws a diversionary request.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t have some water ... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Sure, would you prefer coffee?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Coffee would be great, I never feel human ‘til my sixth cup. Grace is having trouble putting this cup of coffee together. She searches in the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Milk. I’m not ...

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Black is fine. The front door opens, Ethan hurries in.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Ethan, Sergeant Burke stopped -

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (interupts Burke) Any news?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: I brought back some items, your son’s clothes. But yes we’re making some progress. Ethan sits beside Grace at the table, takes her hand. Grace drops her head, Ethan waits for more news.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I thought, the nature of the injury indicates that the SUV was fitted with a grill guard.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: The nature of the injury?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: The autopsy results indicate a grill guard.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Josh suffered a sharp blow to the rib cage which fractured several ribs, and unfortunately drove one into his heart. He died instantly, no pain.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: (lies) The medical officers assured me.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You’re looking for a dark SUV with a grill guard. Anything more?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: It helps us narrow the field somewhat. We’re still working on the headlight glass and we’re canvasing the area. On Sunday we intend to set up checkpoints at the time of the accident. Question drivers who may have passed.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: But its been seven days now.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: He could be in Mexico by now.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: These investigations can take time..

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: If you catch him? What will happen to him?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: He’1ll be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Which is what?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Depending on the circumstances he could get ten years in prison ... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What does depending on the circumstances mean?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: The state of Connecticut has a variety of sentencing criteria that have to be assessed ...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand, he killed our son?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How many people get away with this?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: You know Mr. Learner, I don’t have the exact figures, but I’1ll get them for you. Rest assured, we are doing everything to get him.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 70
dialogues.text: INT. LEARNER HOUSE. ETHAN’S STUDY - DAY 71 Ethan watches as the state trooper car drives away, then heads for his computer. ON SCREEN: googles Hit and Run, Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Do you think I should wash them? He turns around. Grace has Josh’s clothes in her arms INT. ETHAN’S STUDY - NIGHT It’s dark now Ethan is on the internet scanning web sites.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: The screen flickers through: Deadlyroads.com., pages related to stats., statue of limitations, victims photos. Grace comes in, kisses him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: She’s asleep now.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You've got to read this. Ten percent of hit and run cases are never resovled. Grace doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Are you coming to bed?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, will you pick up some groceries on the way home?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You have to leave the house soon, Grace.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I can’t, Ethan, not yet. He holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From afar: As Ethan ascends the steps, he is stopped several times by WELL WISHERS who offer handshakes, pats on the back, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe FORTY STUDENTS, whispering gravely among each other. Then Ethan enters. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Hi there. Okay. I guess you all know that we lost our son Josh last week. (a beat) I know from all your emails that you grieve with me. Now I need to move forward. The best thing you can do to help me is for us all to plunge back into our work. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: (opens file) Today we pick up with our investigation of the twenty four hour news channels, where all the news is breaking, and all the commentators are righteous. They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go back to where it all started with Ted Turner aand CNN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s rental car pulls into the lot.
75 76 Dwight is walking past Cutter’s office, the door is half open. Steve Cutter is talking to somebody we can’t see.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Dwight, you got a minute? INT. CUTTER & ASSOCIATES. CUTTER’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 77 Dwight walks into Jack’s office - and sees Ethan on the couch looking up toward him.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh ... ah... hello. Sorry I didn't ...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Dwight, this is Professor Ethan Learner. My associate Dwight Arno. Ethan lost his son Josh in that terrible hit and run last week over by Reservation Road. You must have read about it? Dwight addresses Ethan - disappointed in some way that Ethan hasn’t identified him.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m truly sorry, Mr. Learner.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Mr. Learner feels he needs our help. Cutter indicates for Dwight to sit beside Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: It’s been over a week. The police haven’t found the killer. They have nothing or they’re not telling us what they have. (hands a folder to Dwight) Here’s their initial report. (beat) I want this man, this ... animal, prosecuted for homicide.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You saw the guy?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: For an instant.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Would you be able to give a description?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I might be able to pick him out of a police lineup, or if I sawa picture. It was very dark.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We’ll start with the state troopers, and the DA’s office, light a fire under their asses, make sure the case is being prosecuted professionally. Then you should think about a civil suit.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What does that ential?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: A civil suit ... ah ... would be ... it’s a suit against ... the person

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (jumping in) The perpetrator.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Uhm, yes, the perpetrator. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We'll sue the perpetrator. A civil suit is an action that results in financiall remuneration.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I want this man to go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You told me earlier that your son died because he was struck by the grill guard. The manufacturer should be sured, let them know these things are for cattle ranches, not our city streets. Dwight and i will get all the relevant detials fromt th police, the corner’s office. I think Donna has all our contact details, right? Here are our cards. Ethan takes the cards. He and Steve stand. Dwight follows, fumbles for a card, and finally hands one to Etahan. Ethan shakes hands with Dwight and Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Dwight turns away as Steve walks Ethan to the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We're sorry for your loss. We’re going to stay with you during this whole process. Ethan leaves. Steve closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What the fuck is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Come on Steve, we don’t do this sort of case.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why not? There are guys in the city making a fortune with this sorta work. Since 9/11 victims comp. is huge. Besides, I feel for the guy, don’t you? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah but I’ve got the Fennelli thing ... You think you can take this one?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What, you’re too busy? Come on Dwight, eleven o’clock, you wander in, what gives these days?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I haven’t been sleeping good.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You see a doctor? Dwight shakes his head “no.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey what have I told you, stop putting things off. Go see a doctor, get a good night’s sleep. We got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn breaks, the sun rises over the Connecticut shore. Ethan and Grace are on a rock at the edge of a cove, watching the sunrise. Ethan has tthe stone urn in his aarms as Grace speaks

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You gave us more than we could have ever asked. You gave us joy and laughter, and the beauty of your music. Thank you my beautiful Josh. Ethan carefully pours the ashes into the sea as they hold each other like two survivors on the last piece of driftwood from a shipwreck. EXT. CHILDREN’S PLAYGROUND - DAY 79A A GROUP OF MOTHERS play with their KIDS on the slides and swings. In the background, Grace’s car speeds past.  80 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School’s out, most of the children have gone. Emma sits on a bench with Ruth Wheldon. Grace’s car pulls up. Ruth sees her.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Hey, there’s your mom. Grace gets out of the car and hurries to them

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry I’m late Mrs. Wheldon.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No problem. Emma was so good today, I wish you could have heard her.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Thank you, she loves your class. As Emma trots on toward the car:

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Can I have a quick word, Mrs. Learner?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Grace, please.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH WHELDON
dialogues.text: Emma shows a lot of promise on the piano. I’d like to give her some extra tutoring after school, free of course. I think it might keep her occupied. Help, you know ...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH WHELDON
dialogues.text: I really want to.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Why don’t I ask her.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH WHELDON
dialogues.text: Of course. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Grace walks to the car.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 81
dialogues.text: INT. GRACE’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 82 Grace gets in.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Why were you late?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry sweetie, I ahh ... Mrs. Wheldon was wondering if you'd like to practice piano with her, after school? Emma looks out the window, doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to do anything you don’t want to do.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Can you hear music if you’re dead? Grace stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 83
dialogues.text: INT. LEARNER HOUSE. ETHAN’S STUDY - LATER - DAY Ethan is on the internet. On screen: Web sites showing damaged cars, advice pages about law suits, civil actions. The printer spews out pages. Emma comes in, hugs him, tighter, more desperate than normal. Grace comes in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How was school honey? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No one wants to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: They're sad about Josh and they don’t want to upset you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Can I watch TV?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Sure. Emma wanders off. Grace looks at Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at this. Ethan pulls up an internet page on law.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In order to prove hit and run you have to be able to prove that the driver knew he someone. If he says he thought he hit a deer, he can get off. Grace is in a different zone.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You think maybe you can make dinner for the kids? Ethan is caught up in the web page.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Sure. Grace realizes.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: The kids? Ethan turns now, takes her in his arms. EXT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE - DAY 84a Dwight and Lucas walk from the car, loaded down with pizza, snacks, soda. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (nervous ) Hey dad, I’ve got something I’ve got to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I got suspended from school.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Why? Get the door. And Lucas does. 85 INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - DAY - CONTINUOUS 85

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Come on, out with it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: I got into a fight, with Paulie Ferrari. He had to have stitches. Dwight grabs Lucas by the shirt and pulls him closer.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What the hell’s wrong with you man? What did you do to him that he had to have stitches? Lucas starts to cry. Dwight suddenly realizes that he’s over-reacting.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Please Dad, don’t!

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to do that. It’s alright. Come on, sit down, tell me what happened. Lucas rubs his eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: We were in the hallway, and Paulie Ferrari threw a water balloon at Benny, but Benny ducked and Mrs. Swanson, the math teacher, came round the corner and got hit in the face. She wanted to know who did it but Paulie wouldn’t own up. So we all got after school detention.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: How did you get into a fight?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: After detention I called Paulie a no-good coward. We started to fight and he banged his head on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: How many stitches?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Six I think.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I don’t want you fighting do you hear me.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: You and mom fight.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, and look where it got us. I don’t want you fighting.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: But Dad, he was a total coward.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Paulie Ferrari doesn’t need you beating him up to know he did wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Mom says I’ve to have no TV tonight. Will you watch the game and tell me the scores.  86 48. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 86 Dwight’s in his living room. (Lucas is in his bedroom) A Redsox game is on the TV - on mute. The cellular phone rings. Dwight picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Oh, Hi Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did he tell you?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, he told me. INT. RUTH’S KITCHEN. NIGHT Ruth is in a corner*. on the phone. We cut between locations.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I think he needs therapy.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He needs to see someone to deal with ...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: It was a fight in a schoolyard, Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He has anger issues ...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What if we went to therapy instead of him?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah you and me. Try to change our lives, lead by example.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Dwight there is no we anymore. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m serious. Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Did he tell you he has to stay in his room?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Tell me this, do you really love Norris?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Boy you never change?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: But do you?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Make sure he stays in his room. No TV. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: (pleads) Wait Ruth, I need to talk to you. CLICK. 87 INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. SPARE BEDROOM - NIGHT 87 Dwight sits on the bed beside Lucas.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: How’s the game going?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: The Sox are ahead three to one. Listen, I want to talk to you about what you said, about your mom and I fighting. Since I was your age, I thought that was how men and women behave. Your grandpa would fly off the handle at the smallest thing. His soup was cold he’d blow his top. I’d sit there wanting to put my fingers in my ears. I’d want to do what you did when your mom and I fought that time. I’d want to run between them, but I knew he’d beat me. I hated him, I hated my mom crying. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: I never wanted to be with him, that’s why he only came over at Christmas. Then, when he got cancer, he said to me how sorry he was, how he never meant it, and he’d die knowing he’d wasted his life. And now I’ve done the same with your mom. But I’1ll never do it to you again - or to her - do you understand? We’re friends right, and friends never hurt each other. He has tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’ll make a pact. Shake on it. No fighting, and if you get mad at your mom, tell her you love her. Deal?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Come on and watch the game.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Thanks dad. INT. ETHAN’S CAR - DAY 88 Ethan drives along a quiet residential street of upscale houses. Ethan glances sideways, clearly sees something, looks back, hits the brakes, and reverses back. He studies a late model dark SUV. Its passenger side fender is damaged, its light is smashed. Ethan studies the SUV, notes the diplomatic plates. His adrenalin is pumping. He pulls out his cell phone, checks the camera function. EXT. ETHAN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 89 Ethan gets out, moves into the driveway, lines up his camera and snaps a photo. He fails to notice the PERSON at the window who watches, looks alarmed, then disappears. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ethan studies the SUV some more, notes the address, gets back into his car, and drives off. The face at the window appears again, watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan is on another street. He checks his phone to make sure he got the shot. A LOCAL POLICE PATROL CAR, races past him, lights flashing. It screeches to a halt, and does a rapid three point turn, as a second POLICE CAR appears and pulls in front of Ethan. COPS jump out, in combat stance, guns drawn.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Get out of your car, with your hands on your head! Ethan is terrified. INT. STATE POLICE BARRACKS. BURKE’S OFFICE - DAY 91 CLOSE ON the photo of the house on the screen of Ethan’s digital camera phone. Reveal Sgt. Burke showing it to Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: It’s the home of a Middle Eastern Diplomat. You can’t be doing this, Mr. Learner.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No one else is.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: That’s not true. We’ve been canvasing houses, visiting repair shops, junk yards. These things

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (interrupts) «+. take time. Time doesn’t exist for me anymore. Do you understand that? I’m in this vacuum, this hole were an innocent life was snuffed out and none of you seen to notice or care. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9la

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: That’s not true. We investigated that car. It was involved ina fender bender a few days ago in the city.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Yes I am, Mr. Learner.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Diplomatic plates. These guys can get away with whatever they want. A diplomat from which country?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: What does that matter Mr. Learner?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this, when was the last time you mentioned my son’s name before today?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: This is not a productive discussion. The diplomat wants to charge you with trespass.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Go ahead, at least there’1ll be one charge to come from my son’s death.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: I persuaded him not to. Why don’t you go home and calm down? INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - NIGHT 9la Dwight has a video camera resting on some books on the breakfast bar. He flips the lcd screen so that he can video himself. He sits on a stool, checks his image in the lcd screen then presses the record button on a remote.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: What I did was terribly wrong. There’s no excuse for it. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: I was afraid that night that I would loose you. You are going to hear bad things about me, things that will make you ashamed. I’m going to go to prison for what I did. I deserve it. People will talk behind your back. It will be hard. I am so sorry but please try to remember these days we had together. They are wonderful days, I thank you for them and hope that one day we can pick up where we left off. I love you so much. Please forgive me. He chokes back a tear. DWIGHT (CONT’D) Please, please, remember I love you more than anything. I hope one day you will forgive me. I never meant to hurt you, but sometimes doing the right thing means hurting those you love most. Dwight finishes the video. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - EARLY MORNING 92 Dwight is at the table in boxers and T-shirt, writing on a legal pad. He’s clearly troubled. He writes, makes a mistake, tears off the page, gets up, paces, smokes a cigarette, sits down, writes again. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. BATHROOM - DAY 93 Dwight shaving, his hand trembling, he cuts himself, washes the soap off, patches the cuts with tissue. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. BEDROOM. DAY 94 Dwight ironing a shirt, searching for socks, putting on a suit, fixing his tie, cleaning shoes with a towel. INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - DAY 95 He folds up the legal paper, finds an envelope in a cluttered drawer, seals the note, writes ‘Lucas’ on the envelope, sets it on the table propped up by salt shaker, gets up to leave. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he’s heading out the door, he turns, hurries back, takes the letter, puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight’s at the front desk. A STATE TROOPER is on the phone. Dwight looks around, watching other TROOPERS, feeling that they will all point a finger at him.

dialogues.speaker: DESK STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m here about the Josh Learner case. The boy ... ahh ... killed on Reservation Road. The phone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: DESK STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Front desk. Yes it is ma’am. No we don’t take reports of lost cell phones. That’s a local police matter ... It’s in the phone book. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: DESK STATE TROOPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lost cell phones, you know how many of those calls we get each day. Can I have your name sir?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Dwight Arno. I’ve got important information - The phone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: DESK STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Excuse me. Hey Jackie, where's Emelda? I’m dying out here. (turns to Dwight) Let me get the case officer for you, Mr. Arno. Take a seat. Dwight nods, sits down, beside another guy watches the hub bub of the front desk. A uniformed officer emerges from a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: (aggressive) You com’er. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He points at Dwight. Dwight stands fearful.

dialogues.speaker: DESK STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Hold it Joe, that’s not the fraud guy. He’s getting printed.

dialogues.speaker: STATE TROOPER
dialogues.text: Sorry. Sergeant Burke emerges and waves to Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: Mr. Arno, come on in. INT. STATE POLICE BARRACKS. BURKE’S OFFICE - DAY 97 CLOSE ON Burke.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: I’m glad you’ve come in Mr. Arno. On Dwight, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kept you. Steve called me a while go to say you’d taken the case. We’ve got to make sure we don’t have a reoccurrence of the last incident .

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE
dialogues.text: He didn’t tell you? Dwight shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT BURKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s been going around photographing damaged SUVs. Scared the daylights out of a Saudi Diplomat. Could have got himself shot. Now he seems to have got a thing in his head that it might have been a diplomat involved in the accident. (he opens a folder) Here’s the reality of the case. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We’re three weeks out, there’s not a decent lead - a dark SUV with a grill guard - a needle in a hay stack. Unless this guy walks in th door we’re gonna have to gonna have to back burner this one. (he shuffles some papers in the file) You'd be doing the guy a favor if you could help him understand. I really feel for the guy but he gave us nothing to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight emerges in a complete fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan GASPS awake. The room is dark. He sits up in bed, reality coming back to him like a nightmare. Grace lies sleeping. He moves toward her, needing her. Half-asleep, she opens herself to him. They kiss, slowly at first, then with greater urgency. They begin to make love, Grace desperately needs thiss physical contact, she grows more passionate, while Ethan tries to slow things down, suddenly they are completely out of wack, Ethan can’t do it. He backs off.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I... ah...

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just can’t, not now.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Is it me?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Don’t be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: You blame me. I see it when you look at me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? The killer’s to blame. No one else. The fucker who stole our son away from us. Ethan swings out of the bed. INT. LEARNER HOUSE - ETHAN’S STUDY. NIGHT 100A CLOSE ON COMPUTER MONITOR: A jazzy clock screen saver flashes 2:06. Then the sound of a key CLICKING, the screen changes to a web page which illuminates Ethan’s face, concentrated on his search.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT. 101
dialogues.text: INT. DWIGHT’S HOUSE. BEDROOM - NIGHT 102 Dwight lies on his bed, stretched out like he’s ready to be crucified. Sleepless. The TV plays some ridiculous infomercial on mute. Dwight lifts his cell phone and presses the “1” key. We hear the voice mail menu through the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: CELL PHONE VOICE
dialogues.text: You have five saved messages ... the first saved message ...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Ethan Learner here, wondering where we are at with the case. Can you call me 555-6469? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CELL PHONE VOICE
dialogues.text: Press seven to erase, nine to save. Dwight presses the “9” key.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ethan Learner. Can I schedule an appointment. I’m wondering about diplomatic immunity. Yeah, anyway please call. 555-6469. Thank ... Dwight closes the phone. He gets up, pulls on a T-shirt, shorts, and grabs a pair of running shoes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pounding of Dwight’s feet on a suburban street, dead of night, no cars, no people. Dwight running hard, trying to run away from himself. INT. LEARNER HOUSE. ETHAN’S STUDY - NIGHT 105 Ethan listening to a pod cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight has stopped under a tree, studies Ethan’s house, through a net curtain, he can see the changing colors from a screen (The computer monitor flashing).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan wanders in, looks toward the bed. Grace has his back to him, her eyes are open, but she doesn’t move. He sits on the bed. Close on Grace, her eyes still open, but now her breathing sounds as though she is sleeping - she’s faking it. Behind her, Ethan studies her back - then he turns, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight. Grace blinks awake and finds Emma sitting on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Dad's asleep downstairs. Grace sits up. EMMA (CONT’D) There’s nothing good to eat anywhere and I’m going to be late. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Grace takes her in her arms - a mother paying attention now. She musters a smile for her daughter and gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: That doesn’t sound very good. Let’s go down together and see what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Grace leads Emma toward the kitchen she looks in, sees Ethan stretched out on the couch sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace loads Emma into the car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with Ethan’s media students. The plasma screen is frozen on an image from Iraq (or Afghanistan). A Persian student, RASHID, is talking angrily.

dialogues.speaker: RASHID
dialogues.text: The cable news channels and the politicians have you Americans deluded.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: How so, Rashid?

dialogues.speaker: RASHID
dialogues.text: They make you believe you are a warrior nation with an invincible army. Your machinery is tough, but this country has grown soft.

dialogues.speaker: BRETT
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Bullshit. There’s no army in the world can defeat us, it’s the terrorists ...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Let him finish, Brett. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RASHID
dialogues.text: You come from Connecticut, one of the most affluent, comfortable, safe places in the world. My people, like most of the world, come from a place that knows pain and suffering, violence, loss.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN GIRL
dialogues.text: AMERICAN GIRL (CONT’D) Are you saying that Persians or Africans feel pain differently from us?

dialogues.speaker: RASHID
dialogues.text: No, no, it is the same. I’m saying they live with pain and death every day. You don’t, you have become soft.

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN AMERICAN
dialogues.text: Poor Americans, Blacks, Hispanics aren’t soft.

dialogues.speaker: RASHID
dialogues.text: Yes, but most Americans are insulated from death. Look at Vietnam, Somalia, Iraq. In the heat of the argument, Rashid has forgotten the circumstances. The class becomes silently uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: RASHID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Americans fall apart at the sight of coffins. They loose their resolve... Ethan is completely absorbed in what Rashid is saying, then he notices the class discomfort. Rashid now notices.

dialogues.speaker: RASHID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Learner, I never meant ...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No, no. These are valid points, anyone else? Silence.  107a 61. INT. ETHAN’S STUDY - NIGHT 107a Ethan is at the computer, listening intently to a podcast blog (or utube video) from one of the victim web sites. This victim is vitriolic.

dialogues.speaker: BLOG FATHER
dialogues.text: When they caught this guy, I was overjoyed. He was so stupid. He took his car to a repair shop and there was blood, my son’s blood, his hair, all over the radiator. The prosecutor told me we’re gonna put him away forever. I walk into the court and I see the prosecutor and this lawyer guy, expense suit, perfect teeth, talking, smiling. The prosecutor comes to me he says the defendant is willing to plea involutionary manslaughter. I said are you crazy. Then he tells me this murderer got himself a hot shot lawyer, and if we go in front of a jury we'll probably loose. Involuntary manslaughter. Six months in jail, three years probation, for murdering my only son. And now he’s out, in the fresh air, polluting it. I can barely breathe now, knowing his foul breath is mixed in. My wife’s fifty now, we have nobody, no children, no grandchildren, our family name all gone. We’re talking about adopting, but its not the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grace is unpacking grocery bags. Food, cleaning products. She’s re-stocking.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I need a hand here. There are more in the car.  108 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight drives along the street toward Ruth’s house. As he approaches Ruth’s house he slows, because he sees: Ethan talking to Lucas who is petting SALLIE. Dwight makes the decision to drive by when Lucas looks up and sees him and waves.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Hey dad ... (runs down garden) Where you going? Dwight stops, reverses, and turns into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, you forgot where I live? Dwight gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: No, I left my wallet in the bank, I was heading back to get it. (a beat) You got your books?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Lucas runs to the porch. Ethan is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Hey Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Hey Ethan, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Good thanks. Lucas is your son?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ruth is my ex.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No kidding. She’s giving my daughter Emma some piano lessons.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s good at that. Lucas arrives. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: We'd beter get going. I dont’ get much time with this guy.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I left a few messages.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I’m sorry. I’ve been waiting for Steve Cutter to get word back from the state troopers.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Forget about the state troopers, they’re useless. We need to talk. When would be a good time?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Let me check my book. 555 6496, right? We’ll schedule something.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Very good. Norris appears at the door as Dwight is at his car.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Dwight?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Hey, Norris. (to Lucas) Come on. (to Ethan) We’ll talk.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Good to see you. Dwight drives off.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: You know Dwight?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve been working with him, legal stuff.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (dubious) I hope it works out. Emma comes out of the house, followed by Ruth. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Hey, Emma’s piece is really coming along, you’re going to be so proud of her at the concert.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You're gonna play at the concert, that’s wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: It’s for Josh. Mom says you can still hear music when you’re dead. Now Ethan needs to get away.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for everything. 109 INT. DWIGHT’S CAR - DAY 109 As Dwight drives Lucas:
